title: Attorney: OSU crash suspect was not drunk, has history of...
text:
Quick facts:
Adacia Chambers' attorney held a news conference Sunday. Chambers is accused of driving her car into a crowd at the Oklahoma State University homecoming parade, killing four and injuring 46. The attorney said he does not believe Chambers was under the influence of alcohol, but she does suffer from mental illness.
An attorney said Adacia Chambers was not under the influence of alcohol during a deadly crash at the Oklahoma State University homecoming parade Saturday.
Chambers’ attorney, Tony Coleman, held a news conference in an attempt to shed light on the incident.
Coleman said that he has ruled out alcohol as the cause of the crash, as Chambers was at the Oklahoma State University “walk around” the night before the crash with her grandmother and aunt. They, along with her boyfriend, said she did not consume alcohol there. He also said she did not display symptoms of someone coming out of a drunken stupor.
The attorney did say that Chambers has a history of mental illness and possibly untreated diabetes.
He believes his client is suicidal and that she claims to go several days without sleeping.
Coleman said he is “not confident at all” that he was communicating with a competent individual.
He said Chambers told him she did not remember much of the crash, telling him it was a “dark period.” She said she could not tell him anything that happened from when she left work Saturday until she was pulled from her car after the crash.
Coleman said he has requested a mental competency evaluation for Chambers. Though he said she is suicidal, she is not currently on suicide watch.
He said Chambers is “not a monster by any means” and that he does not foresee a murder charge.
[ View the story "OSU crash suspect's attorney holds news conference" on Storify ]
